G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount of damages sought by Plaintiff exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and therefore falls within the jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223A, § 5 because the cause of action arose in Norfolk County, Massachusetts, at the Premises located at 125 Washington Street, Quincy, MA.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 5.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223A, § 5 because the cause of action arose in Norfolk County, Massachusetts, at the Premises located at 125 Washington Street, Quincy, MA.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a business owner in control of premises open to the public owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, including business invitees such as Plaintiff.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The excerpt is a short concurring discussion focused on the continued treatment of trespassers and the problems with status-based classifications (trespasser/licensee/invitee). It does not itself articulate or apply a rule about a business owner’s duty of reasonable care to maintain premises open to the public, nor does it mention business invitees or the general duty owed to lawful visitors. While the main Mounsey opinion does address broader duty principles, this particular cited passage does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a business owner in control of premises open to the public owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, including business invitees such as Plaintiff.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the Massachusetts common-law duty of an owner or possessor of land toward lawful visitors and describes that duty as including the obligation to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers. Although the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, its articulation of the general premises-liability duty squarely supports the proposition about a business owner’s duty to lawful visitors, including invitees such as the plaintiff.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988).”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant, as the owner/operator of the restaurant, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the floors, passageways, and common areas in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn patrons of any dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known through the exercise of reasonable care.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely adopts and applies the general premises-liability standard that a property owner or occupier owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe and to protect them from dangers the owner knows or should know about. Although the context is snow and ice in a mall parking lot rather than a restaurant interior, the court expressly states that the same reasonable-care duty applies to all hazards on the property, which encompasses maintaining floors, passageways, and common areas in a reasonably safe condition and protecting patrons from known or reasonably knowable dangers.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–83 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant, as the owner/operator of the restaurant, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the floors, passageways, and common areas in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn patrons of any dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known through the exercise of reasonable care.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms the general Massachusetts rule that a store owner must maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and exercise reasonable care, in line with Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343. While the case focuses on modifying how notice is proved via the mode-of-operation approach, it repeatedly states that a store owner owes invitees a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe and to protect them against dangers the owner knows or should know of through reasonable care. That matches the duty language in the proposition.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). … Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965), states: “A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if, but only if, he (a) knows or by the exercise of reasonable care would discover the condition… and (c) fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner may be found negligent where it creates a dangerous condition or fails to remedy or warn of a condition that it knew or reasonably should have known about.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the duty of a party in control of premises to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe or to warn of dangers that are not likely to be known to patrons but are known or should be known to the defendant. It then applies that principle in the context of a foreign substance on stairs, discussing liability where the defendant created the condition or had actual or constructive knowledge of it. This aligns closely with the proposition about negligence for creating or failing to remedy/warn of a known or reasonably knowable dangerous condition.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance.”

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: In addition, the statements of other staff members that they had been “dodging that puddle” for a while evidence Defendant’s actual knowledge of the hazard and that it had existed long enough to permit a reasonable opportunity to correct or warn of it.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition refers to statements by other staff members saying they had been “dodging that puddle” as evidence of the defendant’s actual knowledge and the hazard’s duration. Gallagher contains no discussion of employee statements like this and instead relies on circumstantial evidence (the condition and location of the ice cream and the cashiers’ vantage point) to infer constructive notice. The case therefore supports the broader concept of notice from circumstances, but not the specific principle about staff statements evidencing actual knowledge and duration of the hazard.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Likewise there was no evidence that the defendant or any of its employees knew of the presence of this ice cream… The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance… Some appreciable time must have elapsed also for the ice cream to have gotten into the condition it was in after the accident as described by the plaintiff.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: In addition, the statements of other staff members that they had been “dodging that puddle” for a while evidence Defendant’s actual knowledge of the hazard and that it had existed long enough to permit a reasonable opportunity to correct or warn of it.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns staff statements about having been dodging a puddle, which would show actual knowledge and duration of the hazard. Deagle does not involve any such statements or actual knowledge; instead, it holds there was no evidence that employees knew of the spill or that it had existed long enough to be discovered and remedied. The case therefore does not support the claimed proposition and in fact illustrates the opposite—lack of evidence of knowledge or sufficient duration defeats liability.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 61 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable steps to address a known, obvious hazard in a frequently used passageway constitutes a breach of the duty of care owed to Plaintiff.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This dissenting opinion concerns causation in a campus rape case and discusses foreseeability of criminal acts, security measures, and locking systems, not a known, obvious hazard in a frequently used passageway. The quoted portion does not address a defendant’s failure to remedy a physical hazard in a passageway or treat such failure as a breach of duty; instead it focuses on whether negligent security measures proximately caused plaintiff’s injury. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific premises-liability proposition stated.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff testified that en route from the dormitory to the refectory, she and the assailant proceeded underneath the chains of a courtyard gate which was not adequately secured, and that the door to the refectory, where the rape occurred, was unlocked. Even if the rape would not have occurred but for those conditions, the jury was unwarranted in finding that those conditions proximately caused her injury. … The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a reasonably foreseeable and natural consequence of Defendant’s failure to address a wet, slippery floor in an interior hallway used by patrons.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the injuries were a reasonably foreseeable and natural consequence of the defendant’s failure to address a wet, slippery floor. Thus, the case, as reflected in this excerpt, does not support the proposition and instead rejects it.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a reasonably foreseeable and natural consequence of Defendant’s failure to address a wet, slippery floor in an interior hallway used by patrons.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns foreseeability of injuries from a wet, slippery floor in an interior hallway used by patrons, i.e., a premises-liability slip-and-fall situation. Jupin v. Kask involves negligent storage of firearms in a private residence and the foreseeability of criminal misuse of a stolen gun, not dangerous floor conditions or patron use of premises. Although the case discusses foreseeability and natural consequences, it does so in a completely different factual and doctrinal context, so it does not provide authority for the specific slip-and-fall proposition stated.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “In the instant case, Jupin argues that the theft of the handgun by Jason, and its subsequent use in the killing of a police officer, was a foreseeable consequence of Kask’s not ensuring the proper storage of firearms kept on her property, and that Kask thus owed the officer a duty of reasonable care. We agree that there was a duty of reasonable care in this case and find no public policy justification for refusing to impose it.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D.proposition: Plaintiff has incurred, and is reasonably expected to incur, medical expenses for the diagnosis, care, and treatment of her injuries in the approximate amount of $1,500 to date, and may incur additional medical expenses in the future.

Fenn v. Mansfield, 336 Mass. 674, 677 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and any future medical costs or loss of earning capacity.

Harlow v. Chin, 405 Mass. 697, 702\u2013.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and any future medical costs or loss of earning capacity.
Harlow v. Chin, 405 Mass. 697, 702\u2013.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses negligence, proximate cause, damages-related statutory caps, collateral source offsets, and charitable immunity, but it never articulates a general rule of Massachusetts tort law that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by a defendant’s negligence, nor does it list elements such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, or future earning capacity. The case is focused on sufficiency of evidence, comparative negligence, statutory limitations, and collateral source rules, not on a broad statement of recoverable damage categories. Therefore it does not serve as authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Harlow v. Chin, 405 Mass. 697, 702\u2013.relevant_excerpt: "The provision is designed to prevent double recovery by a plaintiff through litigation. It also protects the plaintiff from double loss of benefits by cancelling the rights of subrogation and perfections of lien previously held by the entities which provided these collateral benefits. G.L. c. 231, § 60G (c). Thus, when the judge deducts the benefits from the damage award, the entity which provided the benefit cannot collect that amount from the plaintiff."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 60F, 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and any future medical costs or loss of earning capacity.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including under G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
